questions.question: What is React and why is it used?

answer_variants.answer: React is a tool for building websites using small, reusable pieces called components. It makes it easier to create fast and interactive user interfaces by only updating the parts of the page that change.

React is an open-source JavaScript library developed by Meta for building user interfaces, primarily for single-page applications. It is used because of its component-based architecture, declarative nature, and efficient rendering via the Virtual DOM.

React is a declarative, component-based view library. It utilizes a Virtual DOM abstraction to perform efficient diffing and batch updates to the physical DOM. It follows a one-way data flow model and uses JSX for transpiling UI structures into JavaScript objects.
Define React and list three core advantages it provides over traditional imperative DOM manipulation.

Think of React like building with LEGO bricks. Instead of building a whole castle as one big solid piece, you build windows, doors, and walls separately and snap them together. If a window breaks, you just replace that one brick instead of rebuilding the whole castle.
A JavaScript library for building component-based user interfaces.

React was created to solve the problem of state management and UI synchronization in large applications. By promoting declarative programming over imperative DOM manipulation, it ensures that the UI always reflects the current state. Its ecosystem, including React Fiber and Hooks, allows for complex state logic to be shared across many components efficiently.
React is like a smart assistant for making websites. You tell it how the page should look for different situations, and it handles all the hard work of making sure the browser shows exactly that.

React's primary value proposition lies in its 'Reconciliation' algorithm and its ability to abstract away the underlying platform, allowing the same conceptual model to target Web (ReactDOM), Mobile (React Native), and VR (React VR).
A declarative, efficient, and flexible JavaScript library for building user interfaces through an encapsulated component model.
Components are like the building blocks of a website. Each part, like a button, a search bar, or a header, is its own component that you can use over and over again.

Components are independent, reusable pieces of UI. They serve the same purpose as JavaScript functions but work in isolation and return HTML via a render function or JSX. They allow for better code organization and maintainability.

A React component is a JavaScript function or class that optionally accepts inputs called 'props' and returns a React element that describes how a section of the UI should appear. They must always start with a capital letter to be recognized as React components in JSX.
Distinguish between Functional and Class components in React and explain why the community has shifted toward Functional components.

Imagine a kitchen. A 'Component' is like a recipe for a specific dish, say 'Blueberry Muffins'. You can use that recipe multiple times to make many muffins, and you can change the flavor (props) to make 'Chocolate Muffins' without changing the basic structure of how a muffin is made.
Reusable, self-contained building blocks of a React application's UI.

Components promote the 'separation of concerns' in the UI layer. By encapsulating logic (state), appearance (JSX), and behavior (event handlers) into a single unit, React allows developers to build complex systems from simple, predictable parts. Modern React favors functional components with Hooks for side effects and state.

Think of components as custom HTML tags you invent yourself. Instead of just using
or

, you can make a tag that contains everything your header needs.

Components are the units of reconciliation in React. High-level patterns like Higher-Order Components (HOCs) and Render Props allow for complex logic sharing, while Lazy and Suspense components enable code-splitting at the component boundary.
The fundamental units of the React programming model that permit the decomposition of the UI into independent, reusable pieces.
JSX is a way to write HTML-like code directly inside your JavaScript. It makes it much easier to see what your website's interface will look like while you are writing the logic.

JSX stands for JavaScript XML. It is a syntax extension for JavaScript that allows us to write HTML structures in the same file as our JavaScript logic. It is eventually compiled by Babel into `React.createElement()` calls.

JSX code is a syntactic sugar for `React.createElement(component, props, ...children)`. It allows developers to express hierarchical structures in a familiar XML-like syntax while maintaining the full power of JavaScript expressions within curly braces `{}`.
Why is JSX preferred in React, and what happens to JSX code during the build process?

It's like a 'mixed-media' collage. Instead of writing a long essay (JavaScript) and then taking a separate photo (HTML), JSX lets you sketch the photo right onto the essay page so everything stays together in one thought.
A syntax extension for JavaScript that looks similar to HTML.

JSX was introduced to improve developer experience by making the UI visual structure explicit within JavaScript code. Although it looks like HTML, it is closer to JavaScript in behavior (e.g., using `className` instead of `class` and `htmlFor` instead of `for` due to reserved keywords). It also provides built-in protection against Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) by escaping values by default.
JSX is like a magic spell that lets you put HTML tags inside your JavaScript files. It's the most common way to build React apps because it's so easy to read!

JSX transformation has moved from `React.createElement` to the new JSX transform in React 17+, which uses `_jsx` functions from the runtime, eliminating the need to have `import React from 'react'` at the top of every file.
An XML/HTML-like syntax used by React that extends ECMAScript so that XML/HTML-like text can co-exist with JavaScript/React code.

The Virtual DOM is a lightweight 'copy' of the real website UI that React keeps in its memory. When something changes, React updates the copy first, figures out the best way to change the real site, and then does it all at once to keep things fast.

The Virtual DOM is a programming concept where a 'virtual' representation of a UI is kept in memory and synced with the 'real' DOM by a library such as ReactDOM. This process is called reconciliation.

The Virtual DOM is an in-memory tree of JavaScript objects representing the UI. When state changes, React creates a new VDOM tree and compares it (diffing algorithm) with the previous one. It calculates the minimum number of changes needed (patches) and applies those to the real DOM.
How does the Virtual DOM improve performance compared to direct DOM manipulation? Mention the 'Diffing' algorithm.

It's like 'Sketching before Painting'. If you want to change a room, you don't start moving the heavy sofa immediately. You draw it on paper first (Virtual DOM), see if it looks good, and only when you're sure, do you move the actual heavy furniture (Real DOM).
An in-memory representation of the UI used to optimize physical DOM updates.

Updating the real DOM is expensive because it involves layout recalculations and repaints. The Virtual DOM minimizes these operations by batching updates and performing a 'Diffing' algorithm that runs in $O(n)$ time (using heuristics like keys). This abstraction also allows React to support other platforms like mobile, where a 'Real DOM' doesn't exist.
It's React's own private 'map' of the website. It's much faster to change a map than to rebuild the actual house!

With the introduction of React Fiber, the Virtual DOM reconciliation process became incremental, meaning React can split rendering work into chunks and prioritize high-priority tasks like user input over low-priority background updates.
A lightweight JavaScript representation of the Document Object Model used to optimize UI updates via reconciliation.
Props are like 'Settings' or 'Parameters' that you pass into a component to tell it what to show. For example, a Button component might take a 'label' prop to know what text to display.

Props (short for properties) are read-only inputs passed from a parent component to a child component. They allow components to be dynamic and reusable by receiving data from above in the component tree.

Props is an object passed to a component function as the first argument. Props are immutable within the child component; they follow a 'top-down' or 'unidirectional' data flow, ensuring that components remain predictable and pure.
Explain why props are immutable and how data is passed from a parent to a far-removed child without 'Prop Drilling'.

Props are like 'Arguments' in a story. If several actors are playing 'The Hero', the script stays the same, but each actor gets a different 'Name' and 'Costume' (Props) to play their version of the part.
Custom attributes used to pass data from a parent component to a child.

Props allow for 'Component Composition'. By passing data (strings, numbers, objects, arrays, or even other components/functions) as props, a parent can control the behavior and appearance of a child. Because they are immutable, a child cannot modify its own props, which prevents side effects and makes debugging easier via 'One-way data binding'.
Props are like labels you put on a box. The box (component) reads the labels to know what to do with itself!

Advanced prop patterns include 'Children Props' for wrapper components, 'Render Props' for sharing logic, and 'Prop spreading' (`{...props}`) for passing all parent data through to an underlying DOM element.
External configuration passed into a React component, acting as a channel for unidirectional data flow.
State is like a component's 'Memory'. It's used to store information that changes over time, like the current text in a search box or whether a menu is open or closed.
State is a built-in React object used to contain data or information about the component. State can change over time; whenever it changes, the component re-renders to reflect the new data.

State is an internal data store managed by the component itself. Unlike props, state is mutable and is updated using the `useState` hook (in functional components) or `setState()` (in class components). State updates are asynchronous and may be batched for performance.
Differentiate between Props and State. When should you use state instead of props?

State is like your 'Current Mood'. Props are like 'The Weather'. Everyone sees the same weather (Props from nature), but each person has their own internal mood (State) that changes based on what happens to them throughout the day.
An internal data source that enables components to be dynamic and interactive.

State is local to the component it is defined in. React uses state to track 'user events' and 'server responses' that influence the UI. When state is updated, React triggers a re-render of the specific component and its children. To manage complex state across many components, developers often 'lift state up' to the nearest common ancestor.
State is a way for a component to 'remember' things. If you click a 'Like' button, the component uses state to remember that the heart should now be red.

State management in React follows 'Immutability' principles; you should never modify state directly but always use the update function. This allows React's reconciliation engine to detect changes by simple reference comparison.
A local, encapsulated data structure maintained within a React component that triggers re-rendering upon modification.

Hooks are special functions that allow you to use React features (like 'Memory' and 'Lifecycle') in simple functional components. They always start with the word 'use', like `useState` or `useEffect`.

Hooks are functions that let you 'hook into' React state and lifecycle features from functional components. They were introduced in React 16.8 to allow stateful logic to be reused without changing component hierarchy or using class components.

Hooks are JavaScript functions that allow for the subscription to React state and lifecycle events. They must follow two strict rules: 1. They can only be called at the top level (not inside loops or conditions). 2. They can only be called from React function components or custom hooks.
List three built-in React hooks and explain the primary purpose of each.

Hooks are like 'Special Tools' in a Swiss Army Knife. Instead of carrying around a giant toolbox (a Class Component), you just 'hook' the specific tool you need (like a screwdriver or a blade) into your small handle (Functional Component).
Special functions that allow functional components to manage state and side effects.

Before hooks, only Class components could have state. Hooks like `useState` handle data, `useEffect` handles side-effects (like API calls), and `useContext` handles global settings. They allow developers to extract stateful logic into 'Custom Hooks', making code more modular and easier to test without the complexity of 'this' binding or lifecycle methods.
Hooks are like 'power-ups' for your components. They let you do cool things like saving data or fetching info from the internet without writing much code.

Hooks utilize an internal array structure based on call order to track state across renders. This is why the 'Rules of Hooks' are mandatory; if the order of hooks changes between renders, React will lose track of which state belongs to which hook.
Encapsulated logic primitives that facilitate state management and lifecycle subscription within functional component architectures.

questions.question: What is the 'root' element in React?

answer_variants.answer: The root element is the 'Entry Point' or the main container in your HTML file where the entire React application is injected and shown.

The root element is an HTML div (usually with the ID 'root') that acts as the container for the React application. React uses a method like `createRoot` to take control of this DOM node and mount the component tree inside it.

In a standard React setup, `ReactDOM.createRoot(document.getElementById('root')).render(<App />)` designates the physical DOM node from which the entire Virtual DOM tree will be managed. Everything inside this node will be handled by React's reconciliation engine.
Explain the role of the HTML 'root' container in a single-page React application.

It's like the 'TV Screen' in your living room. The TV itself is just a frame (the HTML). React is the 'Show' being broadcast. The root element is the exact space inside the plastic frame where the images actually appear.
The single HTML element that serves as the mounting point for a React app.

A React application is usually a Single Page Application (SPA). The HTML file is nearly empty, containing just one `
`. React builds the entire UI and injects it into this one div. This allows for smooth transitions and fast performance because the browser doesn't have to load a complete new HTML file every time the user clicks a link.
Think of it as the 'Starting Line' for your code. React looks for this specific spot in your HTML and says 'I'll take it from here!'

While most apps have one root, React supports multiple roots in a single page. This is useful for integrating React into a legacy non-React application, where different parts of the page (like a widget) are powered by separate React instances.
The DOM node ancestor for all elements managed within a specific React application instance.
CRA is a 'Starter Kit' that sets up everything you need to build a React website with just one command. It handles all the complex setup in the background so you can just start coding.

Create React App is an officially supported CLI tool for bootstrapping a new React project. It provides a pre-configured environment with zero build configuration, including a development server, Babel, and Webpack setup out of the box.

CRA is a scaffolding tool that sets up a modular project structure using Webpack for bundling, Babel for transpiling ES6/JSX, and Jest for testing. It abstracts away the complex 'Toolchain' configuration into a single dependency (`react-scripts`).
What are the benefits of using a boilerplate tool like Create React App compared to setting up a project manually?

It's like a 'Pre-built PC'. Instead of buying every tiny screw and chip and soldering them together (configuring Webpack/Babel), you just buy the pre-built box, plug it in, and start playing games immediately.
An official tool to create a new React project with no configuration effort.

CRA was the standard for years, but as web tools evolved, 'Ejecting' (revealing the hidden config) became a headache for some. Modern developers now often prefer faster alternatives like Vite or framework-driven approaches like Next.js, but CRA remains the most famous 'one-click' entrance into the React ecosystem for students.
The easiest way to start learning React! It creates all the folders and files you need so you don't have to guess where things go.

CRA uses 'Hidden' configuration. If a user needs custom Webpack features not supported by CRA, they must 'eject'. This process is irreversible and results in a highly complex and verbose set of configuration files that the developer must then maintain manually.
An integrated development environment for React that hides the underlying build toolchain configuration.

questions.question: What is the difference between an Element and a Component?

answer_variants.answer: An Element is a 'Description' of what you want to see (like a photo of a button). A Component is the 'Factory' that creates those elements (like the machine that makes the button).

A React Element is a plain JavaScript object describing a component instance or DOM node and its desired properties. A Component is a function or class that can accept props and returns an Element tree.

Elements are the building blocks of React apps. They are immutable and represent the 'current' view. Components are the reusable logic units. You call a component to generate a tree of elements which React then compares to update the DOM.
Define both Element and Component in React and explain why elements are immutable while components can have state.

A Component is like a 'Cookie Cutter'. An Element is like a 'Cookie'. You can use the cookie cutter as many times as you want to make many cookies, but once a cookie is baked, its shape is fixed (immutable).
A component is a blueprint; an element is what the blueprint creates.

In JSX, `<MyComponent />` is the creation of an element. Under the hood, this becomes a JS object like `{ type: MyComponent, props: {} }`. React 'executes' the component function to see what it wants to return, resulting in a deeper tree of elements until it reaches 'host elements' like `<div>` or `<span>`. This recursive process is how the Virtual DOM is built.
You write Components in your code. React uses those Components to make Elements, which are the actual things you see on the screen.

Elements are 'cheap' to create. React's architecture depends on the ability to discard and recreate element trees on every state change, as the reconciliation algorithm is optimized for these rapid object comparisons rather than deep mutations.
Component: A template or logic unit. Element: An immutable object representation of a UI node or component instance.
